title: DOL’s Scalia Can Help Rewrite Fiduciary Rule
text:
As a corporate lawyer, Eugene Scalia played a key role in killing the DOL’s fiduciary rule. But as the new head of that department, he won’t have to recuse himself from working on a revamped version.

That’s the determination of career government lawyers, The Wall Street Journal reports.

The department’s ethics lawyers decided that applicable ethics rules and the Trump administration’s ethics pledge do not require Scalia to recuse himself, Kate O’Scannlain, the department’s solicitor, said.

“The new rulemaking is not a ‘particular matter involving specific parties’ and litigation related to a prior rule which the secretary handled while in private practice has ended,” she said in a statement.

The Obama-era rule had required brokers and advisors offering advice on retirement accounts to adhere to a fiduciary standard, but the financial-services industry challenged it in court. Following an appeals court’s decision to vacate the rule, the Trump DOL (under Scalia’s predecessor Alexandar Acosta) disclosed it would develop a new version.

The ethics lawyers’ decision isn’t sitting well with consumer advocates.

“I don’t know what type of legal gymnastics lawyers had to do to come to such a ridiculous conclusion,” said Dennis Kelleher, chief executive of Better Markets, a group that advocates for stricter oversight of Wall Street. “Everyone can now be highly confident the Department of Labor will propose and finalize a rule that the industry will cheer and retirees will pay the price for.”

--Ross Snel
description: Government ethics lawyers have determined that new Labor Secretary Eugene Scalia can participate in the department’s work on a revamped fiduciary rule.
